message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and description of the pathogen suggest that the most likely diagnosis is malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. None of the options match this description.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest acute otitis externa, which is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. P. aeruginosa produces an exotoxin that acts locally. Among the options, only C. diphtheriae produces an exotoxin that acts locally, causing tissue damage and inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of acute otitis externa, which is commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus. These pathogens can produce exotoxins that damage the ear canal. However, the question asks for an organism that produces a toxin similar to one produced by another pathogen. Among the options, only Corynebacterium diphtheriae produces an A-B exotoxin that is similar in structure and mechanism of action to the pertussis toxin produced by Bordetella pertussis. However, C. diphtheriae is not a common cause of acute otitis externa.
